title: Finding $$\lim_{x\to-3} \frac{1}{\left(x+3\right)^4}$$ from the right
text: Given that $$n$$ is a positive even integer, what is the limit?

title: Explanation Previous Limit
text: From the function $$\lim_{x\toa} \frac{1}{\left(x-a\right)^n}$$, we know that $$n$$ $$=$$ $$4$$ in $$\lim_{x\to-3} \frac{1}{\left(x+3\right)^4}$$ from the right. According to the Infinite Limits from Positive Integers Theorem, if $$n$$ is a positive even integer, then $$\lim_{x\toa} \frac{1}{\left(x-a\right)^n}=+\infty$$. Since $$4$$ is a positive even integer, this means that $$\lim_{x\to-3} \frac{1}{\left(x+3\right)^4}$$ from the right is $$+\infty$$.
